column4: please run you command with LANG=en on the front, like "LANG=en apt-get install mysql-server..."
I tried with --configure too but without luck

well, maybe someone else have a better ideia, but if I had this problem the thing I was going to do is to bakup /var/lib/dpkg/status then search for mysql-server inside it and manually remove the package from there, after them try running the apt-get install again
gonna try that, I had already removed /var/lib/mysql too
well, but remember of removing only the mysql-server package, not those who say to have him as dependency
do u mean removing this? http://pastebin.com/wJ9mCvy1
exactly (don't forget to backup status file), after that run apt-get install again
you may see if there isn't other mysql-server package, that you showed was the only one you finded ?
I was running mysql-server-5.0 whithout problems but when I upgraded to mysql-server-5.1 something went wrong and both instances screwed up
okay, take a look at the status file and search for mysql packages there... you may need to remove more them one from the list to apt-get reinstall all it is needed
if you like I could give you some help, but for that I would like to inspect the file
thanks but I have removed every description of the mysql-server package of status file and luck yet :(
that is odd... did you changed any repository or this happen after an update?
this happened after upgrading to mysql-server-5.1
geekphreak also when I'm installing it and asks to change root password it shows: http://pastebin.com/CZgwCcxw may be this can be helpful
